questions.answer_description:
To restore files or folders from the recovery point, go to the virtual machine and choose the desired recovery point.
Step 0. In the virtual machine's menu, click Backup to open the Backup dashboard.
Step 1. In the Backup dashboard menu, click File Recovery.
Step 2. From the Select recovery point drop-down menu, select the recovery point that holds the files you want. By default, the latest recovery point is already selected.
Step 3: To download the software used to copy files from the recovery point, click Download Executable (for Windows Azure VM) or Download Script (for Linux
Azure VM, a python script is generated).
Step 4: Copy the files by using AzCopy
AzCopy is a command-line utility designed for copying data to/from Microsoft Azure Blob, File, and Table storage, using simple commands designed for optimal performance. You can copy data between a file system and a storage account, or between storage accounts.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/backup/backup-azure-restore-files-from-vm https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-use-azcopy
questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have an Azure Linux virtual machine that is protected by Azure Backup.
One week ago, two files were deleted from the virtual machine.
You need to restore the deleted files to an on-premises computer as quickly as possible.
Which four actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:

discussion.content:
For Linux:
1 - From the Azure portal, click File Recovery from the vault
2 - Select a restore point
3 - Download and run a script
4 - Copy the files by using AZCopy

For Windows:
1 - From the Azure portal, click File Recovery from the vault
2 - Select a restore point
3 - Download and run a script
4 - Copy the files by using File Explorer
No. of Q Missing, not displaying with Multiple choices. web team, please assist to resolve these q issue, and will be better if displayed. missing on many pages. specially last 10-pages.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You are creating an Azure load balancer.
You need to add an IPv6 load balancing rule to the load balancer.
How should you complete the Azure PowerShell script? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:

discussion.content:
I have tested this and the answer is
To add a backend pool to LB1: Network Contributor on RG1
To add a health probe to LB2: Network Contributor on RG1

Explanation by LowerSouth 1 month, 2 weeks ago
To add to the backend pool, write permission is required on the Resource Group because it writes deployment information. So the answer is Network Contributor on RG1
* Note* permission is also required on the resource group of any added NIC, but that is outside the scope of the question.

To add a probe, just Network Contributor on the load balancer is required. (Although permission on the VNET is also required, but that also seems to be outside of the scope of the question)

So the thing is, once you give Admin1 Network Contributor on RG1, assigning Network contributor permission to the public load balancer is unnecessary.

comments.content: Even Network contributor on LB2 is not enough, for both cases you need the permission on RG1

The question is not about the final role needed to accomplish both task, but the one needed for each task individually :
- To add a backend pool to LB1: Network Contributor on RG1
- To add a health probe to LB2: Network Contributor on LB2

else the question would ask for only one answer...

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have an Azure subscription named Subscription1 that contains a resource group named RG1.
In RG1, you create an internal load balancer named LB1 and a public load balancer named LB2.
You need to ensure that an administrator named Admin1 can manage LB1 and LB2. The solution must follow the principle of least privilege.
Which role should you assign to Admin1 for each task? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:

DRAG DROP -
You have an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant that has the initial domain name.
You have a domain name of contoso.com registered at a third-party registrar.
You need to ensure that you can create Azure AD users that have names containing a suffix of @contoso.com.
Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate cmdlets from the list of cmdlets to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:

discussion.content:
Add a DNS Zone
Create the domain name
Verify
 https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/dns/dns-web-sites-custom-domain

comments.content: You link the wrong url! https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/fundamentals/add-custom-domain create custom domain - create txt record - verify

Agree with ExamGuy01.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/fundamentals/add-custom-domain
Answer is
1. create custom domain to Azure AD
2. Add DNS information to the domain registrar (Create a TXT record with domain registrar)
3. Verify custom domain name in Azure AD

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Yes -
Contoso is moving the existing product blueprint files to Azure Blob storage.
Use unmanaged standard storage for the hard disks of the virtual machines. We use Page Blobs for these.

Box 2: No -
Box 3: No

discussion.content: do we get case study questions in exam? please advise

contoso requires a storage account that support Blob storage 
contoso requires a storage account that support Azure Table storage 
contoso requires a storage account that support Azure File storage

contoso requires a storage account that support Blob storage - yes
contoso requires a storage account that support Azure Table storage - No
contoso requires a storage account that support Azure File storage - No
